questions.question: Question 1: What type of lesion is angiofibroma?
questions.explanation:
Angiofibroma is a histologically benign tumor but locally aggressive. It is a rare tumor, though it 
is the commonest of all benign tumors of the nasopharynx. Angiofibroma arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. Recurrent spontaneous epistaxis is the 
most common presentation of angiofibroma. 500 
Sold by @itachibot The investigation of choice is a CT scan. There is anterior bowing of the maxillary sinus's posterior 
wall, which is referred to as the Holman-Miller sign/ antral sign. Surgery is the treatment of choice. Radiotherapy is used for tumors with intracranial extension. 
Chemotherapy is used in combination with surgery or as monotherapy when surgery is 
contraindicated.

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient presented with difficulty in breathing and swallowing. On examination, a painless 
nasopharyngeal mass was noted. Angiofibroma was suspected. Which of the following 
statements is false about this condition?
questions.explanation:
The image shows a nasopharyngeal mass suggestive of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma 
(JNA), which is causing difficulty in breathing and swallowing. It is more common in males. The tumor is predominantly seen in adolescent males in the second decade of life. It is thought to 
be testosterone dependent. Patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the 
nasopharynx which is activated to form angiofibroma when male sex hormones appear. A biopsy is contraindicated due to the risk of severe bleeding. The vessels lack contractile 
components and hence bleeding cannot be controlled with adrenaline.

Question 3: 496 
Sold by @itachibot A 16-year-old boy presents to you with complaints of nasal obstruction and frequent nose 
bleeds. CT scan shows Holman-Miller sign. You suspect a benign tumour of the nasopharynx. 
What is its most common site of origin?

options.c: Anterior wall of the sphenoid bone

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of 
the diagnosis of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). It most commonly arises from the 
sphenopalatine foramen. From here the tumour grows into the: • Nasal cavity • Nasopharynx • Pterygopalatine fossa • Pterygomaxillary fossa • Infratemporal fossa Given below is CT showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus- 
Holman-Miller sign. 501

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following features will not be seen in a patient with nasopharyngeal 
angiofibroma?
questions.explanation:
Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma presents with rhinolalia clausa (hyponasal speech), not rhinolalia 
aperta (hypernasal speech). The patients present with progressive nasal obstruction and hyponasal speech due to mass in the 
postnasal space. Profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis is the most common presentation. 
The patients may be markedly anemic due to repeated blood loss. Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion occur due to obstruction of the eustachian 
tube. It can spread to the orbit giving rise to proptosis and broadening of the nasal bridge, giving rise to 
frog face deformity. Other features include swelling of the cheek and cranial nerve palsies (II, III, 
IV, and VI).

questions.question:
Question 5: A mother brought her 16-year-old boy with a unilateral profuse nosebleed. After successful 
control of bleeding, a CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of juvenile angiofibroma. What is the 
reason for it to cause excessive bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Angiofibroma is made of vascular and fibrous tissues. Vessels of angiofibroma lack contractile 
components, they are just endothelium-lined spaces with no elastic or muscle coat. This accounts for severe bleeding as the vessels lose the ability to contract. Hence the bleeding 
cannot be controlled by the application of adrenaline. Therefore, the biopsy is contraindicated.

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following deformity is likely to be seen in a patient with juvenile nasopharyngeal 
angiofibroma?
questions.explanation:
Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma when spreads to the orbit, lead to proptosis and broadening of the 
nasal bridge, giving rise to frog-face deformity. 502 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Gorilla-like facies are seen in acromegaly. Option C: Bird-like facies are seen in the Pierre-Robin sequence. Option D: Lion-like facies are seen in Paget's disease of bone when craniofacial bones are 
involved.

questions.question:
Question 7: A teenage boy presents to you with recurrent epistaxis and hearing loss. On examination, he 
has a frog-face deformity and conductive hearing loss. Which of the following is the 
investigation of choice to diagnose the condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Investigation of choice 
to diagnose this condition is contrast enhancement CT scan (CECT). MRI scan can be used complementary to CT to see soft tissue extensions of the tumor. Carotid angiography shows the extent of the tumor, its vascularity, and feeding vessels which 
mostly come from the external carotid system. Embolization of vessels can be done at this time to 
decrease bleeding at operation. A biopsy is contraindicated in this condition as it can lead to massive hemorrhage.

questions.question:
Question 8: In a suspected case of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, CECT is performed. Which of the 
following signs will help diagnose this condition?
questions.explanation:
Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus in CECT of head and neck is called 
an antral sign or Holman-Miller sign, which is pathognomonic for angiofibroma. Option A: Tram track sign is used to differentiate optic nerve sheath meningiomas from optic 
gliomas. Optic nerve sheath meningiomas will show a positive tram-track sign. Option C: Stripe sign/ tigroid pattern represents a specific pattern of demyelination, with sparing 
of perivascular white matter. It is seen in metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD). 503 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Eye-of-a-tiger sign represents marked low signal intensity of the globi pallidi on T2W 
MRI images.

questions.question:
Question 9: Imaging of a patient with recurrent epistaxis shows the following finding. Which of the 
following statements is false about his condition? 498 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Tumor does not have a capsule
options.c: Digital palpation should never be done in OPD

questions.explanation:
The image shows anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, which is called 
an antral sign or Holman-Miller sign. It is pathognomonic for angiofibroma. Recurrence of 
juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is common. It is a rare tumor but is the commonest benign tumor of the nasopharynx. It commonly arises 
from the sphenopalatine foramen. It does not have a capsule. Digital palpation should never be done until at the time of operation, as it can lead to severe 
hemorrhage.

questions.question:
Question 10: A teenager has a mass in his nasopharynx that has minimally spread into the sphenoid sinus 
with no lateral extension. Which stage of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma could this be?
questions.explanation:
The mass has spread into the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension, so it's Stage 1B according 
to the Radkowski classification. Multiple classification systems exist for the staging of juvenile nasal angiofibroma, of which the 
most commonly used ones are the Fisch and Radkowski classification systems: Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Radkowski, et al): Fisch staging system of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumor 
seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional

questions.question:
Question 11: A young boy with a history of frequent nosebleeds and unilateral nasal blockage. CT scan 
shows Holman- Miller sign. It also shows the presence of a mass in the nasopharynx that 
extends into and occupies the pterygopalatine fossa. What is the best treatment for this 
patient?
questions.explanation:
The clinical picture suggests that of stage IIB nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Surgery is the 
mainstay of treatment of angiofibroma for stage I and stage II tumors. Radiotherapy is indicated in stage III where there is an intracranial extension or when the tumor 
is unresectable. Chemotherapy can be used for very aggressive resurrect tumors and residual lesions. Stages of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Hormonal therapy was used in the past, but not anymore. 505

questions.question: Question 12: Radiotherapy is indicated when the spread of angiofibroma extends to which site?
questions.explanation:
Radiotherapy is used for intracranial extension of disease when tumour derives its blood supply 
from the internal carotid system. Recurrent angiofibromas have also been treated by 
radiotherapy. 506 
Sold by @itachibot Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma
